text: Simply saying where is on its own, of course, is...
Où est ?
So once more, how would you say where is the campsite ?
Où est le camping ?
The toilets in French, the toilets are...
Les toilettes.
How would you say where are the toilets ?
Où sont les toilettes ?
Now you'll have noticed that I've intentionally led you into a trap there,
into saying where is the toilets ?
The reason I've done that is that frequently,
because saying where is, which is...
Où est ?
is very comfortable for English speakers.
I've found that English speakers tend to use it for everything,
even when they're talking about something where there's more of one.
Because obviously in English we don't say where is the toilets,
we say where are the toilets.
It's the same in French.
So to say where are in French, we will say...
Où sont ?
Où sont ?
So the word for are is...
Sont.
It's spelt S-O-N-T.
But of course, T is not in for luck, so it's not pronounced.
And it sounds a very French word.
So once again, the word for are is...
Sont.
So how would you say...
Where are the toilets ?
Où sont les toilettes ?
How would you reply if someone asked you and you would say...
The toilets are over there.
Les toilettes sont là-bas.
Of course, we stay with the word for are, which is...
Sont.
Rather than using is, because it is would not be correct in English, so it isn't in French either.
It is in French.
What was it is ?
C'est.
It is is very useful as it allows you to have a very wide range of expression in French.
So for instance, how do you think you'd say in French, it's possible ?
C'est possible.
As mentioned earlier, words in English that end in A-B-L-E and I-B-L-E exist in French as well,
except they're pronounced a bit differently.
A-B-L-E in French is pronounced...
A-B-L-E.
And I-B-L-E is pronounced...
I-B-L-E.
If you simply change this pronunciation, you can then use those English words in French.
So once again, how would you say table in French ?
Table.
And possible ?
Possible.
How would you say it's possible ?
C'est possible.
In addition to those I-B-L-E and A-B-L-E words, we have some others which we've already gone through.
For instance, the words that end in I-C and I-C-A-L in English.
In French, those words end in I-C-E.
I-C-E.
It's a bit like the sound you'd say when you were shocked, or perhaps if someone stood on your foot.
So, changing these words slightly, how would you say it's exotic ?
C'est exotique.
One thing to note again about French is that because the last letter isn't pronounced,
it may be hard from listening to know exactly how something is spelt.
For instance, it is, which in French is...
C'est.
C'est is spelt C'est.
But of course, T is not in for luck, so it's not pronounced.
However, if the word that follows it is begins with a vowel,
it is possible to more or less push the sound of the T that's at the end of the C apostrophe E-S-T
into the following words and then to actually pronounce it.
So, we will say it is exotic again, just as we did a moment ago, which is...
C'est exotique.
But you may also hear French speakers pronounce it as...
C'est exotique.
C'est exotique.
You may be able to hear there the T as it's pushed into exotic.
C'est exotique becomes...
C'est exotique.
As a person learning French, you can choose either way, whichever it is you prefer.
However, it's important to be aware that the French will tend to push those letters into other vowels.
And so, you need to begin to attune your ear to the way French people speak the language.
But both forms are equally correct in spoken French.
This is the end of CD3.
The end of CD3.
